bestBHT.bht: The debate over the word oft in this text has puzzled scholars, with two possible interpretations: oft or diligently. This has led to uncertainty in determining its true meaning. One possibility is that it refers to washing diligently up to the elbow, using one hand clenched. On the other hand, it might imply washing one's own hands. Regardless, it is clear that the act of washing, as performed by the Scribes and Pharisees, was a formal and ceremonial tradition. This highlights their strict adherence to external rituals and traditions.

Henry Alford: The word oft thus rendered has perplexed all the Commentators.
Of the various renderings which have been given of it, two only seem to be admissible: (1) that given in the text, oft; and (2) diligently.
Between these two it is not easy to decide.
Philip Schaff: The literal sense is the correct one, but it conveys no meaning to the ordinary reader without a long explanation.
The main point is, that the ceremony was formal.
Archibald T. Robertson: Diligently (πυγμη). Instrumental case, with the fist, up to the elbow, rubbing one hand and arm with the other hand clenched."
The middle voice νιψωντα means their own hands."
This verb is often used for parts of the body while λουω is used of the whole body
John Gill: they wash their hands to the elbow
the command concerning washing of hands is, from the words of the Scribes
And this tradition of the elders, the Scribes, and Pharisees, strictly observed.

bhtAttempts.bht: The word oft in this verse has been a cause of confusion among scholars and various renderings have been proposed, including diligently. The meaning of the word is not easy to determine. On one hand, it could refer to washing diligently, up to the elbow, with one hand clenched, and often used for parts of the body. On the other hand, it could imply their own hands being washed. Pharisaism seemed to be prevailing, and while the literal sense of the verse is correct, it may require a lengthy explanation for it to be fully understood. The main point here is that the washing ceremony was a formal act, following the tradition of the Scribes and Pharisees.

The word oft in this passage has raised much debate among scholars, with two possible meanings: oft or diligently. The confusion lies in the fact that this verb is often used for parts of the body, while λουω, meaning to wash, is used for the whole body. The ceremony of washing here was a formal one, adhered to strictly by the Scribes and Pharisees. Although the true meaning may not be immediately clear to the average reader, it highlights the emphasis placed on traditions and external rituals.

The perplexing word oft in this verse can be understood in two ways: either as oft or diligently. Scholars have debated this, as the verb often refers to washing parts of the body, while another term, λουω, is used for washing the entire body. The washing ceremony described here was a formal act, diligently followed by the Scribes and Pharisees, reflecting the emphasis they placed on traditions and external rituals. Though the meaning may not be immediately apparent, it underscores the significance of these customs in their religious practice.

The debate over the word oft in this text has puzzled scholars, with two possible interpretations: oft or diligently. This has led to uncertainty in determining its true meaning. One possibility is that it refers to washing diligently up to the elbow, using one hand clenched. On the other hand, it might imply washing one's own hands. Regardless, it is clear that the act of washing, as performed by the Scribes and Pharisees, was a formal and ceremonial tradition. This highlights their strict adherence to external rituals and traditions.

The word oft in this passage has puzzled commentators, who contemplate two possible meanings: oft or diligently. The difficulty lies in deciding between them. One option is to interpret it as washing diligently, up to the elbow, with one hand clenched, a verb often used for body parts. Conversely, it could signify their own hands being washed. It is evident that the washing ceremony described here was a formal ritual followed strictly by the Scribes and Pharisees, emphasizing the significance they placed on traditions and external practices.
